properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of dense fog with near zero visibility will affect the region tonight and into early Tuesday morning. In addition, with overnight temperatures near or a little below the zero degree mark in some areas, untreated roads may suddenly become icy and slippery. Motorists should drive according to the weather and road conditions and allow extra time to reach their destination. The Tuesday morning commute may be affected in many areas. Fog is expected to lift Tuesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-03T17:00:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-03T07:01:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0525475112.2020
Area: Brockville - Prescott, Gananoque - Mallorytown
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR GOLDEN (March 2, 2020 16:00 local Mountain time - Cranbrook) The Ministry of Environment & Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Interior Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Golden due to high concentrations of dust that are expected to persist for the next 24 hours. This advisory will be updated tomorrow. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have underlying medical conditions such as breathing or lung conditions, hay fever, asthma or persons who react strongly to dust. If you are experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheeze, follow the advice of your health care provider. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at: https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-landwater/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-03T15:43:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-03-02T23:44:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1625545018.2020
Area: East Columbia
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 2 to 4 millimetres of freezing precipitation is expected beginning this evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry weather expected later this week. Time span: Wednesday evening until Thursday morning. Locations: Great Northern Peninsula. Snowfall amounts: 10 to 15 cm (by midnight Wednesday night). Rainfall amounts: 5 to 10 mm (by early Thursday morning). Remarks: Snow is expected to begin over the Great Northern Peninsula late in the day on Wednesday with strengthening easterly winds. The snow is forecast to change to rain later Wednesday night and then taper to flurries later on Thursday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-04T00:53:20-00:00

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog with tricky driving conditions tonight and early Tuesday morning. Areas of dense fog with near zero visibility will continue to affect the region tonight and into early Tuesday morning. In addition, with overnight temperatures near or a little below the zero degree mark, untreated roads may suddenly become icy and slippery. Motorists should drive according to the weather and road conditions and allow extra time to reach their destination. The Tuesday morning commute may be affected in many areas. Fog is expected to lift Tuesday morning. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, mild temperatures and gusty winds are expected mid-week. Time span: Wednesday and Wednesday night. Locations: central and eastern Newfoundland. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm (higher amounts possible over southern areas). Rainfall warnings have been issued for Channel-Port aux Basques to Connaigre. Maximum wind gusts: southerly 70 to 100 km/h (strongest near the coast). Remarks: Rain will begin along the south coast of Newfoundland on Wednesday morning and will spread over central and eastern parts of the island by early Wednesday afternoon. The rain may be preceded by a short period of freezing rain over some areas, but temperatures are anticipated to rise quickly over most locations. The mild air combined with the rain could cause significant snowmelt and runoff. The rain is forecast to taper off Wednesday night. In addition, a period of strong southerly winds is expected over most areas on Wednesday night. Localized flooding may occur in low lying areas. Where possible, ice and snow should be cleared from storm drains in advance of this rainfall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-04T01:01:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-03T09:02:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3463041935.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. The coldest wind chill values will be between minus 55 and minus 60. Extreme cold wind chill values will continue tonight and Tuesday. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-03T20:16:34-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor weather expected over Eastern Quebec midweek... A low pressure system will intensify over the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Wednesday. It may bring heavy snow and strong winds producing blowing snow over the Lower St Lawrence, the Gaspé Peninsula and the North Shore. The Southern Gaspé Peninsula could also see a period of freezing rain. Conditions are gradually expected to improve on Thursday. These poor weather conditions could delay travel. Please consider modifying any non essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-03T18:47:26-00:00

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. High concentrations of pollutants should persist through Tuesday morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-03T17:33:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2020-03-03T04:34:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4080341177.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, snow and strong winds expected later this week. Time span: Wednesday through Thursday. Locations: western and southwestern Newfoundland. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm, with higher amounts along the south coast (Wednesday). Rainfall warnings have been issued from Channel-Port aux Basques to Connaigre Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm or more (Thursday). Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly 80 to 100 km/h (Wednesday). Wind warnings have been issued for Bay St. George to Corner Brook and may be extended further north along the west coast. Remarks: Rain will begin over southwestern Newfoundland on Wednesday morning and will spread up the west coast on Wednesday afternoon. The rain may be preceded by a short period of freezing rain over some areas, but temperatures are anticipated to rise quickly over most locations. Colder air will return Wednesday night, causing the rain to change to snow. Snow will then likely continue through Thursday and may be heavy over some areas, especially along the Long Range Mountains. In addition, a period of strong southeasterly winds is expected over most areas on Wednesday afternoon or evening. Gusty west to southwesterlies will then follow for Thursday. Localized flooding may occur in low lying areas. Where possible, ice and snow should be cleared from storm drains in advance of this rainfall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-04T01:00:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-03T09:01:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1229068504.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A major winter storm is expected. A low pressure system will intensify over the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Wednesday. It will give total snowfall amounts of 30 to 40 centimetres through Thursday. Strong winds will locally cause blowing snow. These poor weather conditions could delay travel. Please consider modifying any non essential travel plans. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Road closures are possible. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Patchy dense fog is appearing on some webcams and in observations from the London-Middlesex to the Belleville area. Visibility is expected to improve Tuesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
